subNodes.conversationText: root

The young witch entered a dilapidated shack. Nature was reclaiming it. A tree was growing through the roof. The ground beside the tree had sunken in, making a gaping hole in what would have been the floor.

Even so, someone was there.
[Continue.]

A man leapt to his feet as <FirstName> came in, nearly tipping over the chair where he'd been sitting. With one hand he steadied it, and with the other drew a blade as if expecting an attack -- but after a quick study of <FirstName>'s face he let the weapon drop.

He might have been less quick to let his guard down if Knott had been visible, but the giant gourd was standing outside, out of view.
[Continue.]
"What are you doing here?"
"Exploring. I thought this house was deserted."
"I see," he said.
"I'm looking for someone. Are you a hunter?"
"I'm looking for someone. Are you a hunter?"
"Do I look like a hunter?"
[Continue.]
He didn't. His paleness hinted at a life indoors, and his clothes were town clothes. There was a bow made of yew and a quiver of arrows in the corner of the room, though. He saw the witch spot it.

The two exchanged names -- his name was Tilen -- but the witch learned little beyond that. He was gruff and said little, and he was wary. He'd seen no one since coming to the woods and knew of no hunters. When <FirstName> brought up the Congress of Moths, he laughed scornfully. He would say nothing about what brought him there or where he'd come from.
"He's very lucky," the young witch thought. "He'd be dead if the Congress of Moths caught him. Strange that they haven't."
"You were quick to draw your blade when I came in. Why?" the witch asked.
"I'm....uneasy," he said. "It's that hole over there."
"The hole?"

"Yes. It's very strange, but I have this dread of it. I can't even get close to it. Every time I try... I think it's a -- what do you call it? A sinkhole. Yes -- and I think it must have formed one night when I was sleeping. It wasn't there when I first got here. I wonder if I'm just afraid of falling in? I've always had a fear of heights. Is it very deep? Can you see the bottom?"
[Continue.]

"Well, I have a bow. But I'm a bad shot. I've been eating nothing but berries since I came out here."

The two exchanged names. His was Tilen. He knew nothing about Nnenne or hunters, and when the witch mentioned the Congress of Moths, he laughed incredulously.
[Continue.]

The man had a lilt that sounded old-fashioned or foreign. There was a curious blankness to him, too. The caginess of a fugitive, perhaps: when it came to the most obvious questions --  why he was there and where he was from -- he told the witch nothing.
"He's in some sort of trouble," the young witch thought to <him/her>self.
"Can I -- tell you something?" he said, staring intently at <FirstName>.
"Ah, here it comes," <FirstName> said to <him/her>self.
"It's that hole beside you. It makes me uneasy."
"Very well, but I only listen to confessions if they're interesting."
"It's that hole beside you. It makes me uneasy."
"If he's on the run, he chose a bad place to run to," <he/she> thought. "He won't last long out here."
"Can I -- tell you something?" he said, staring intently at <FirstName>.
"You were quick to draw your blade when I came in. Why?" the witch asked.
"It's that hole beside you. It makes me uneasy."
"The hole? The hole in the floor?"

"Yes. I can't go near it. Every time I try I shrink back... It wasn't here when I found this place. The floor must have collapsed one night when I was sleeping. Can you see into it from where you are? Can you see the bottom?"
[Continue.]
<FirstName> could. Rocks and debris from the house littered the area below, which was slick with moisture. From what <he/she> could see, there was nothing remarkable about it.
<FirstName> reported what <he/she> saw.

"Really? That's all?" He seemed relieved. "Let me take a look."

He started toward the hole but faltered on the way. He began shaking, and <FirstName> saw beads of sweat on his forehead.
[Continue.]
"I can't do it," he said. "Is there something -- down there you don't see? Something -- horrible?"
"If there is, my witchcraft may be of use."
"I'd be grateful if you took a look," he said, slumping into his chair. He was fatigued and out of breath. He looked terrible. <FirstName> wondered if he was ill.
[End.]
<FirstName> looked into the hole again.
<He/She> craned <his/her> head in an effort to see more, but it was too dark.
"If there is something down there, my witchcraft may be of use."
"I'd be grateful if you took a look," he said, slumping into his chair. He was fatigued and out of breath. He looked terrible. <FirstName> wondered if he was ill.
"Not my concern if there is."
"No, it isn't." Tilen slumped in his chair. "Still... I'd be grateful if you took a look." He was fatigued and out of breath. He looked terrible. <FirstName> wondered if he was ill.
[End.]
"It's very dark, very scary. It may be bottomless," teased the witch.

Tilen tried to make sense of this, then coughed or laughed -- it was hard to tell which -- and said, "Ah. You're toying with me."

He started toward the hole but faltered on the way. He began shaking, and <FirstName> saw beads of sweat on his forehead.
[Continue.]
"I'm a witch. I go where I please. Who are you?"
"A witch? I know the stories, like everyone. Eldest Lady and her moving house... But I didn't really think..." He trailed off.
"I'm looking for someone. Are you a hunter?"
